ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: The event name for which the data was collected
Medications and supplements taken by mother in first trimester
Medications and supplements taken by mother in second trimester
Medications and supplements taken by mother in thirdtrimester
Medications and supplements taken by mother postnatally
Baby Gender
Baby's Gestational Age At Birth
Baby's gestational age at time of scan (field derived from Enrol Step 3)
Baby's age (days) on scan date [scan_appt_date]
Baby's weight at time of scan
Baby's head circumference at time of scan
Baby's length at time of scan
Baby's skinfold thickness at time of scan
Medications and supplements given to baby
Which milk types have ever been given to the baby? (1, Mother's Breast Milk)
Which milk types have ever been given to the baby? (2, Donor Milk)
Which milk types have ever been given to the baby? (3, Formula)
Which milk currently makes up the majority of the baby's feeds?
Notes: 0 = No selection; 1 = Mother's breast milk; 2 = Donor milk; 3 = Formula

ElementDescription: Scanner Validation ID
Radiology Score
Notes: 1 = Normal appearance for age; 2 = Incidental findings with unlikely significance for clinical outcome or analysis (e.g. subdural haemorrhage. Isolated subependymal cysts. Mild Inferior vermis rotation); 3 = Incidental findings with unlikely clinical significance but possible analysis significance (e.g. Several punctate lesions or other focal white matter/ cortical lesions not thought to be of clinical significance); 4 = Incidental findings with possible clinical significance. Unlikely analysis significance (e.g. Isolated non brain anomaly e.g. in pituitary / on tongue); 5 = Incidental findings with possible/likely significance for both clinical and imaging analysis (e.g. Major lesions within white / matter

ElementDescription: Poor image quality for radiology score?
